messages.message: Yeah, also had some thoughts about this. Moving to a trash directory is easy, keeping track of when the file was deleted and then having a nb-reaper-like job to actually delete it is the more complicated part. If it were just s3, we could easily store the time of deletion in the metadata. But for NFS/other drives we don’t have this luxury.
If all our files were indexed by something like elastic search, this would be much more easily doable.

There are definitely hacks we can throw in to make this work now/temporarily, but they’re pretty gross. E.g. could move to trash + write metadata into the first N bytes of the file, But I’m not sure we want to be putting hacks in the fileservice.
